thread.title: N'Keal Harry, 5-star WR, sets official visits to Oregon State Beavers, Oregon Ducks
thread.title_full: N'Keal Harry, 5-star WR, sets official visits to Oregon State Beavers, Oregon Ducks | OregonLive.com

author: Andrew Nemec | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: N'Keal Harry, 5-star WR, sets official visits to Oregon State Beavers, Oregon Ducks
text:
The Oregon Ducks and Oregon State Beavers have spent the past few years in very different places in the world of college football, but the two programs have collided on the recruiting path this fall.
Rivals five-star wide receiver N'Keal Harry , out of Chandler High School (Chandler, Arizona), recently set up a visit to Corvallis on October 24 with Oregon State quarterback commit Mason Moran and U.S. Army All-American running back Chase Lucas , both high school teammates of his.
But he also recently decided to take an official visit to Oregon for the Civil War on Friday, November 27.
Moran, his quarterback, called Harry's commitment to the Beavers "a longshot," but the dynamic 6-foot-3, 211-pound playmaker said that's not entirely accurate.
"It's not that the odds are long, people just think I won't consider them based on (my offers)," he said. "For me, it's whatever fits the best and whatever coaches I bond with the most. I wouldn't say it's a longshot. It all depends on the visit. It's a real possibility."
Given the change in direction in Corvallis, Harry said he is anxious to experience the new environment surrounding the Beavers.
"I'm excited to see everything, especially going up there with Chase and Mason," he said. "I'm excited to see how they coach and how they play."
This week, Harry scheduled another official visit in Oregon â€“ this time to Eugene for the Civil War content on November 27.
Harry, who is rated the No. 20 prospect in the country and the No. 2 wide receiver by Rivals, sees himself as an ideal fit in the Oregon offense.
"I'm really excited for that. It'll be great to see a rivalry game and I really like coaches at Oregon," he said. "I need to talk to the coaches a little bit more, but I really think I'd fit in the offense and could play at Oregon."
Prior to his trip to Eugene, however, Harry plans to narrow his current list of 10 schools down to five.
"That will probably be within the next couple of weeks here," he said. "I have to look at the list I have right now and break it down from there."
Oregon and Oregon State have spent many years battling it out on the gridiron. This fall, the two programs are also competing for a five-star wide receiver.
-- Andrew Nemec
anemec@oregonian.com
@ AndrewNemec
